pages.body:
The 7th Floor Group was the term used by an unnamed individual to discuss a group of officials as allegedly meeting regularly to discuss Clinton-related Freedom of Information Act requests. The term appeared in an FBI investigation report on the Hillary Clinton email controversy. Instead of following the State Department's usual procedure of rolling releases of FOIA documents, the group allegedly wanted to release them all in January of 2016. They were overruled by the State Department Office of Information Programs and Services (IPS).[1]

The documents include an interview with an unnamed individual, who suggested that Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests related to Clinton went through this alleged group: "There was a powerful group of very high-ranking STATE officials that some referred to as "The 7th Floor Group" or "The Shadow Government." This group met every Wednesday afternoon to discuss the FOIA process, Congressional records, and everything CLINTON-related to FOIA/Congressional inquiries," the FBI's interview summary said."[1]

#References

1 Rosenfeld, Everett (17 October 2016). "New FBI release on Clinton email probe refers to 'Shadow Government'". CNBC.


---

This article was removed from wikipedia, and cloned/mirrored to ZeroWiki. See the web archive [here.](https://web.archive.org/web/20161107170931/https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/7th_Floor_Group)

# Proxies

A proxy is a website that you can reach using any web-capable device that runs a multi-user [[ZeroNet]] instance. *[Learn how to host one](/kindlyfire.bit/?Post:9:Running+a+ZeroProxy)*. You can also install [[AWS Shadow Socks]].

There also is a website dedicated to listing proxies: [zeroproxies.bit](/zeroproxies.bit), but it is outdated.

## List of working proxies

- https://bit.surf:43110/ (replacing https://bit.no.com:43110/)
- https://www.zerogate.tk/ (Adding new sites is disabled)
- https://zeronet.maxweiss.io/
- https://alilialili.ga/
- https://fuckcf.cf/ ((Qualys SSL Labs grade A+) + HSTS Preload, TLS 1.3 or QUIC)
- https://zn.maly.io/
- https://zeroml.ml/ (Can also proxy Freenet)
- http://cvhb5yx2qdclb76m.onion/ (Onion, only usable over [[Tor]])

## List of meta proxies

What's meta proxy? See [this post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1_1M4Ab8CUu3byziHVvNXLHmPezC4Lg9hvNJ)

- https://zero.acelewis.com/
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1KSAMg1UFuUa17do6uSBni5jpNt9wsYrP6

## List of broken proxies

***These proxies do not work anymore.***

- https://zeronet.korso.win/ (FileServer Error, Certificate expired)
- https://proxy1.zeronet.functor.xyz/ or https://proxy1.zeronet.functor.xyz:10443/ (IPv4 and IPv6 with TLSv1.2 + modern FS ciphers only (Qualys SSL Labs grade A) + HSTS + secure cookies) (Certificate expired)
- https://zero.arukascloud.io/
- https://0netproxy.ml/
- https://0proxy.ml/
- https://proxy.th3nd.com
- https://zeronet.iikb.org/
- http://zero.btnova.org/
- https://onlyzero.net/ (and https://onlyzero.net:43110/ )
- http://zerowrohotccypak.onion/ (Onion, only usable over [[Tor]])
- https://proxy1.zn.kindlyfire.me/ (http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:12_1FTFKztuv4Z5uy6iS83k9hB2xtS6yFnDxx/ZeroNet+proxy+proxy1+zn+kindlyfire+me+shutting+down)
- https://proxy2.zn.kindlyfire.me/
- http://wrewolf.com:43110/ (0.4.0, supports ZeroMe)
- http://proxy.zeroexpose.com/ (pron)
- http://zeroexposedcuclo.onion/ (Onion, only usable over [[Tor]])
- http://zero.pags.to:43110/
- https://zeroproxy.atomike.ninja/
- http://zerobit.io:43110/
- http://epdb6k6hj4rttycg.onion/ (Onion, only usable over [[Tor]])
- http://zeronet.crypt.cat:8080/
- https://www.zeropro.xyz/ (TLS certificate expired; removed on 2017-01-11; server down)
- http://wrewolf.com:43110/ (removed on 2017-01-11; 502 Bad Gateway from reverse nginx proxy)
- http://ampgb4cmyghof5rh.onion/ (Onion, only usable over [[Tor]])

# Welcome to ZeroNet

[[ZeroWiki]] is a wiki platform for [[ZeroNet]], the distributed web network based on [[Bittorrent]], [[Bitcoin]] and [[Tor]]. 

[[ZeroWiki]] is public, [[cloning|clonable]]. Wikis can be used for taking notes, storing snippets, sharing knowledge by creating [[FAQ]]s and documentations, keeping track of your goals, or as a simple to-do lists. See the [[help|help page]] for a more in-depth view of how it works.

## Useful pages

- [[zeronet|What is ZeroNet ?]]
- [[zite|What is a "zite"?]]
- [[ZeroWiki:Format|ZeroWiki writing format]]
- [[List of Zites]]
- [[Dev ideas|Development ideas]]
- [[proxies|List of proxies, allowing you to view ZeroNet from clearnet]]
- [[zerowikisandbox|Sandbox, you can play with it before editing other pages]]

*Please note that [[ZeroWiki]] is still beta software, it may have bugs and lack some features
[[ZeroWiki:Issues|Propose features and report bugs here]].*

# Kaffiene

Kaffiene is a [[search engine]] for [[ZeroNet]] [[zite]]s. It uses naive and [[regex]] queries to search through a plain-text index of sites along with hand-picked tags. The site freely shares its index and is [[cloneable]]. There are currently over 600 sites listed in the index.



## See also

* [[bwoi]]
* [[ZeroSearch]]
* [[Zearch]]


## External links

* [Official zite](/kaffiene.bit/) [üìé](/1Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba)
* [on 0list](/0list.bit/?Topic:2_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh/Kaffiene+Search+Engine) [üìé](/186THqMWuptrZxq1rxzpguAivK3Bs6z84o/?Topic:2_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh/Kaffiene+Search+Engine)
* [developer blog (Kaffie)](/kaffie.bit/) [üìé](/1N6zp6jCXPBktNMPfe7UJBpQGyfCq7k2M8)

# InterPlanetary File System

**InterPlanetary File System** (**IPFS**), is a content-addressable, [[peer-to-peer]] hypermedia distribution protocol. [[Nodes]] in the IPFS network form a distributed file system. IPFS is an [[open source]] project developed by Protocol Labs with help from the open source community. It was initially designed by Juan Benet.

IPFS seeks to connect all computing devices with the same system of files. In some ways, IPFS is similar to the Web, but IPFS could be seen as a single [[BitTorrent swarm]], exchanging objects within one [[Git]] repository. In other words, IPFS provides a high throughput content-addressed block storage model, with content-addressed hyperlinks. This forms a generalized Merkle DAG. IPFS combines a distributed hashtable, an incentivized block exchange, and a self-certifying namespace. IPFS has no single point of failure, and nodes do not need to trust each other.

The file system can be accessed in a variety of ways, including via FUSE and over HTTP. A local file can be added to the IPFS filesystem, making it available to the world. Files are identified by their [[hashes]], so it's caching-friendly. They are distributed using a Bittorrent-based protocol. Other users viewing the content aid in serving the content to others on the network. IPFS has a name service called IPNS, a global namespace based on PKI, serves to build trust chains, is compatible with other NSes and can map DNS, .onion, .bit, etc. to IPNS.

## External Links
* [Website](https://ipfs.io) (clearnet!)
* [IPFS Introduction Video (YouTube)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8CMxDNuuAiQ) (clearnet!)
* [HTTP is obsolete. It's time for the distributed, permanent web (IPFS gateway)](https://ipfs.io/ipfs/QmNhFJjGcMPqpuYfxL62VVB9528NXqDNMFXiqN5bgFYiZ1/its-time-for-the-permanent-web.html) | [Local address](http://127.0.0.1:8080/ipfs/QmNhFJjGcMPqpuYfxL62VVB9528NXqDNMFXiqN5bgFYiZ1/its-time-for-the-permanent-web.html)
* [Interplanetary Networks](https://ipn.io/) (clearnet!)

# Git

Git is a widely used [[source code]] management system for software development. It is a distributed revision control system with an emphasis on speed, data integrity, and support for distributed, non-linear workflows. Git was initially designed and developed in 2005 by Linux kernel developers (including Linus Torvalds) for Linux kernel development.

## External links

* [Official website](http://git-scm.com/) (clearnet!)

# Bitcoin

**Bitcoin** is a digital asset and a payment system invented by [[Satoshi Nakamoto]], who published the invention in 2008 and released it as [[open-source]] software in 2009. The system is [[peer-to-peer]]; users can transact directly without an intermediary. Transactions are verified by network [[nodes]] and recorded in a public distributed ledger called the [[blockchain]]. 

The ledger uses bitcoin as its unit of account. The system works without a central repository or single administrator, which has led the U.S. Treasury to categorize bitcoin as a decentralized virtual currency. Bitcoin is often called the first [[cryptocurrency]], although prior systems existed. Bitcoin is more correctly described as the first decentralized digital currency. It is the largest of its kind in terms of total market value.

## External links

[Bitcoin Wiki](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Pqq7TeAyCdVDqm2EN6PE9QVKHawzWyFmc)

[Bitcoin on the English Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin) (clearnet!)

# ZeroWiki Issues

## Bugs
+ Don't work with special chars in page name (example - try to create page with _ char)
+ [FIXED? need confirmation] None of the icons visible on Win8.1 + Chrome

Please report bugs in this section.

## Feature Requests

Please add feature requests here.
+ Localization for pages (example - we have [[Help]] page with default language (en) but if we add ?lang=$name you can get localized version)
+ upload content (images) but only as optional files
+  interface localization 
+ if 2 people editing page at the same time - show alert
+ Global 'recent changes' page
+ highlight difference between version when open history (like github)
+ protected pages
+ moderators
* [DONE] creative commons license for easier (legal) modification of articles
+ anchor to elements
+ code element
* seperate ZeroWiki: sites from normal sites
* support [ [wikisite|alternative naming] ]
* Optional short user entered message for edits shown on the History page
* Talk page for each wiki page to keep discussions about edits off the articles
* More markdown elements support like quotes >, tables, etc

### On The Issue Of ClearNet Links

Recently there have been articles edited and written to include links to relevant clearnet sites. However, there's no notice of which links point where without examining the target URL (which may not be possible or enabled in some browsers). Personally, I think there should be either an automatic marker for clearnet sites, or a notice on the article to alert users of what links leave ZeroNet. It's also worth noting that in the future, some users may be accessing ZeroNet without access to the traditional internet/web, making these essentially dead links. Thoughts?

----

### To Link Is To Do

There's a problem with ZeroNet links because the host part http://host:port differs a lot from client to client and especially for proxies:

Try a link via 127.0.0.1:43110 using a proxy or with a different port number in your local setup... it'll fail...

* [Official zite](http://127.0.0.1:43110/search.kaffie.bit/) [üìé](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba)

```
* [Official zite](http://127.0.0.1:43110/search.kaffie.bit/) [üìé](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba)
```

Link without HOST part works with proxies too:

* [Official zite](/search.kaffie.bit/) [üìé](/1Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba)

```
* [Official zite](/search.kaffie.bit/) [üìé](/1Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba)
```

...seen something like that @ Himalaya...

...bye¬≤ from Alfie...

----

-> but there is afaik an addon, that makes urls like http://search.kaffie.bit usable ‚Ä¶ that would probably break it, not sure so. But agree, relative paths would be better.

----

Using 127.0.0.1-Links force you to use a local client.
Proxies soon will be a common entry point to ZeroNet.
Stripping http://host:port so kinda getting an absolute path relative to current host and port work best for me...

-- *yeti 20160314-1933-GMT*.

----

There definitely needs to be a standardized way of linking to ZeroNet sites. Relative linking works, but it indeed absolutely breaks the chrome extension. The other option is to simply build the URL depending on what the visitor's current URL is. It's not a simple 'a' tag and requires a bit of javascript magic, but certainly works. Kaffiene does something like this.
See [[Search Engine]]

# Welcome to ZeroWiki

Welcome to ZeroWiki, a new kind of **publishing platform for ZeroNet**, the distributed web we all love.

ZeroWiki is a public [[wiki]] software and most of the pages in this site are editable, anyone can modify it to add or improve the contents. See the [help page](http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Help) to learn how it works.

Wikis can be used for taking notes and storing snippets, to create FAQs and documentation, to keep track of your goals or as a simple To-Do list. As it happens with most collaborative tools, it can be used in many different ways, even to build your own community.

Use it however you want, ZeroWiki is free and [[cloneable]] from your [[ZeroNet]] connected sites.

## Testing

For testing please use the [[ZeroWiki:Sandbox]].

## ZeroWiki is beta software

This project is still in beta phase and it may have bugs or lack features.

Please report bugs and add feature requests to the [[ZeroWiki:Issues]] page.

## Discuss ZeroWiki
[Discussion this Wiki engine on ZeroTalk](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:5_1LRrd96P7FiTcsyNXVzPM5jtpQoH1B4gYf/ZeroWiki+a+wiki+for+ZeroNet) [üìé](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:5_1LRrd96P7FiTcsyNXVzPM5jtpQoH1B4gYf/ZeroWiki+a+wiki+for+ZeroNet)

There definitely needs to be a standardized way of linking to ZeroNet sites. Relative linking works, but it indeed absolutely breaks the chrome extension. The other option is to simply build the URL depending on what the visitor's current URL is. It's not a simple 'a' tag and requires a bit of javascript magic, but certainly works. Kaffiene does something like this.

# Zite

A Zite is a [[ZeroNet]] website. Zites have the notable difference of being entirely decentralized and work even if the visitor is offline. Zites are designed to be entirely open source and freely shared. Zite owners can also make their site [[cloneable]]. This ensures content is not censored and cannot be forcefully taken down.

However, due to how the site is distributed and viewed, sites must be entirely contained within local HTML and Javascript files. Information for the site can be stored in an SQLite database or in JSON files.

Zites require the private key generated with the address in order to be edited or published. Users of the zite have a subdirectory they may edit within the zite's file structure.

Various attempts have been made to index and search the hundreds of zites that have been created. [[Search engine]]s like [[Kaffiene]] or [[ZeroSearch]] allow searching through hand-crafted indexes using key terms. While other zites, like [[0list]] or [[ZeroCentral]], allow user submissions to generate a list.

# Zite

A Zite is a [[ZeroNet]] website. Zites have the notable difference of being entirely decentralized and work even if the visitor is offline. Zites are designed to be entirely open source and freely cloneable. This ensures content is not censored and cannot be forcefully taken down.

However, due to how the site is distributed and viewed, sites must be entirely contained within local HTML and Javascript files. Information for the site can be stored in an SQLite database or in JSON files.

Zites require the private key generated with the address in order to be edited or published. Users of the zite have a subdirectory they may edit within the zite's file structure.

Various attempts have been made to index and search the hundreds of zites that have been created. [[Search engine]]s like [[Kaffiene]] or [[ZeroSearch]] allow searching through hand-crafted indexes using key terms. While other zites, like [[0list]] or [[ZeroCentral]], allow user submissions to generate a list.

# Welcome to ZeroWiki

Welcome to ZeroWiki, a new kind of **publishing platform for ZeroNet**, the distributed web we all love.

ZeroWiki is a public [[wiki]] software and most of the pages in this site are editable, anyone can modify it to add or improve the contents. See the [help page](http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Help) to learn how it works.

Wikis can be used for taking notes and storing snippets, to create FAQs and documentation, to keep track of your goals or as a simple To-Do list. As it happens with most collaborative tools, it can be used in many different ways, even to build your own community.

Use it however you want, ZeroWiki is free and [[cloneable]] from your [[ZeroNet]] connected sites.

## Testing

For testing please use the [[ZeroWiki:Sandbox]].

## ZeroWiki is beta software

This project is still in beta fase and it may have bugs or lack features.

Please report bugs and add feature requests to the [[ZeroWiki:Issues]] page.

# Cloneable

A [[zite]] is cloneable when 'cloneable' has been set to true in it's [[content.json]] file. This enables the site to be easily cloned from the [[ZeroNet]] homepage. Cloning a site duplicates it and sets any data files back to their default. The result is a new site running on the same code and structure as the source. Many zites take advantage of the cloning feature and allow ZeroNet to be flexible and free. [[ZeroTalk]] uses it to create custom, independent, reddit-like forums. [[ZeroWiki]] can be cloned to make new specialized wikis. [[Kaffiene]] has enabled cloning to encourage competition and growth amongst ZeroNet [[search engine]]s. Most users, however, are probably most familiar with cloning [[ZeroBlog]] to have their own personal blog site.

# Kaffiene

Kaffiene is a [[search engine]] for [[ZeroNet]] [[zite]]s. It uses naive and [[regex]] queries to search through a plain-text index of sites along with hand-picked tags. The site freely shares it's index and is [[cloneable]]. There are currently over 300 sites listed in the index.

# Zite

A Zite is a [[ZeroNet]] website. Zites have the notable difference of being entirely decentralized and work even if the visitor is offline. Zites are designed to be entirely open source and freely cloneable. This ensures content is not censored and cannot be forcefully taken down.

However, due to how the site is distributed and viewed, sites must be entirely contained within local HTML and Javascript files. Information for the site can be stored in an SQLite database or in JSON files.

Zites require the private key generated with the address in order to be edited or published. Users of the zite have a subdirectory they may edit within the zite's file structure.

Various attempts have been made to index and search the hundreds of zites that have been created. [[Search engine]]s like [[Kaffiene]] or [[ZeroSearch]] allow searching through hand-crafted indexes using key terms. While other zites, like 0list.bit, allow user submissions to generate a list.

Welcome to ZeroWiki, a new kind of **publishing platform for ZeroNet**, the distributed web we all love.

ZeroWiki is a public [[wiki]] software and most of the pages in this site are editable, anyone can modify it to add or improve the contents. See the [help page](http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Help) to learn how it works.

# ZeroSearch

ZeroSearch is the first [[search engine]] for [[ZeroNet]] [[zite]]s. It uses naive queries to search through a plain-text index of sites along with hand-picked tags. There are currently over 400 sites listed in the index.

# Search Engine

A site used to search through the hundreds of [[ZeroNet]] sites and find relevant content. There are a few main search engines for [[ZeroNet]]. The most popular is [[Kaffiene]]. Other popular sites include [[ZeroSearch]] and [[Bwoi]]. All three search through a plain text index of sites. [[Zearch]] uses a more traditional approach of categorizing and searching content.

# Zeropolls

A [[zite]] where you can vote and comment on polls. It's also possible to create new polls. Your votes are just [[pseudonymity|pseudonymous]], not [[anonymity|anonymous]].
